sentences.english: Third category called" little wife" middle, be a yes-man, like a doormat.
sentences.chinese: 第三類叫“小媳婦型”中層，唯唯諾諾，像個受氣包。

sentences.english: She likes the submissive person,and doesn't hear any advices.
sentences.chinese: 她喜歡唯唯諾諾的人，根本聽不進所有其他人的勸告。

sentences.english: I don't know why there are all yes-men around me.
sentences.chinese: 我不知道爲什麼人我身邊都是些唯唯諾諾的人。

sentences.english: She likes those yes men and never accept others' advices.
sentences.chinese: 她喜歡唯唯諾諾的人，根本聽不進所有其他人的勸告。

sentences.english: He stood aside meekly when the new policy was proposed.
sentences.chinese: 當有人提出新政策時，他唯唯諾諾地站在一旁。

sentences.english: She likes yesmen and never takes the advices from all other people.
sentences.chinese: 她喜歡唯唯諾諾的人，根本聽不進所有其他人的勸告。

sentences.english: The Government, compliant as ever, gave in to their demands.
sentences.chinese: 同往常一樣唯唯諾諾，對他們的要求作出讓步。

sentences.english: I'm told he's only a yes-man.
sentences.chinese: 我聽說他是個唯唯諾諾的人。

sentences.english: He's useless at his job and only got promoted because he's a yes-man.
sentences.chinese: 他沒有才能，能升職只因爲他是個唯唯諾諾的人。

sentences.english: No matter where he worked, he always kowtowed to his superior.
sentences.chinese: 不論他到哪兒工作，都對他的上級唯唯諾諾。

sentences.english: Followership You don't have to be a spineless5) yes-person to be a good follower.
sentences.chinese: 服從精神你無須凡事唯唯諾諾纔算是一名好的追隨者。

sentences.english: He compared the situation to a marriage in which the wife was bossing around her henpecked husband.
sentences.chinese: 他將之比作婚姻關係，妻子頤指氣使而丈夫唯唯諾諾。

definition: to defend sb (a relative, friend or oneself) despite knowing that that person is in the wrong
to nod one's head and bow (idiom); bowing and scraping/unctuous fawning
open the net on one side (idiom); let the caged bird fly/to give one's opponent a way out/lenient treatment
to push oneself forward/to seek fame/to be in the limelight/same as 出鋒頭|出锋头[chu1 feng1 tou5]
to call loudly (idiom); to get people's attention/to make one's views known
to weigh up sb's words and observe their facial expression (idiom)/to discern what sb thinks from his body language
lit. to point at the mulberry tree and curse the locust tree/fig. to scold sb indirectly/to make oblique accusations (idiom)
old: to reap the consequences of one's words (idiom, from Mencius); modern: to go back on one's word/to blow hot and cold/to contradict oneself/inconsistent
to submit to humiliation (idiom); to suffer in silence/to swallow one's anger/to grin and bear it
